docs.lead_paragraph: President Obama spends a second consecutive day in New York on Tuesday, this time concentrating his time at the United Nations General Assembly. In addition to speaking at a climate change summit hosted by the U.N.'s secretary general, Ban Ki-Moon, he'll meet with several world leaders.
docs.abstract: The United Nations swarms New York; the Senate health-care bill gets a high-profile markup.
docs.snippet: The United Nations swarms New York; the Senate health-care bill gets a high-profile markup.

docs.lead_paragraph: In an interview with The New York Times ahead of Tuesday's 9 a.m. start of committee action on his far-reaching legislation to revamp the health care system, Senator Max Baucus, the Montana Democrat and chairman of the Finance Committee, talked about why medical care in the United States will only get better -- and how a fall-back provision for a public health insurance plan could be the trick to push the bill through the Senate with 60 votes.

headline.main: Chatting With Baucus, Over a Cup of Buffalo Blend

docs.abstract: Before his hand-crafted health bill starts getting picked apart in the Senate Finance Committee, Max Baucus talks of this hopes for a better medical system.
docs.snippet: Before his hand-crafted health bill starts getting picked apart in the Senate Finance Committee, Max Baucus talks of this hopes for a better medical system.

byline.original: By DAVID M. HERSZENHORN and ROBERT PEAR

docs.lead_paragraph: Tired of the government bailing out banks? Get ready for this: officials may soon ask banks to bail out the government.

headline.main: F.D.I.C. May Borrow Funds From Banks

docs.lead_paragraph: One year and two bailouts later, Bank of America is moving to extricate itself from Washington's grip.

headline.main: BofA Moves to Reduce Dependence on Aid

docs.abstract: One year and two bailouts later, with the financial industry on the mend, Bank of America announced several measures on Monday to reduce its reliance on federal aid and to extricate itself from Washington's grip.
docs.snippet: One year and two bailouts later, with the financial industry on the mend, Bank of America announced several measures on Monday to reduce its reliance on federal aid and to extricate itself from Washington's grip.

docs.lead_paragraph: The bank, under investigation by several agencies for its conduct while acquiring Merrill Lynch, is trying to smooth relations with regulators.

headline.print_headline: Bank of America Seeks to Pay Back Federal Aid
